title: 'Pause' of US intelligence sharing with Ukraine poses unprecedented challenges for allies
summary: The suspension is a major handicap for Ukraine, which had hitherto relied on US data to offset the imbalance of power with Moscow. Although Europe is ready to take up the slack, it can't provide the same level of support.

title: Trump invites Iran leader to nuclear talks – or else
summary: US President Donald Trump's outreach marks a departure, at least in tone, from the hardline stance that marked his first term and could put him at odds with close ally Israel, which last year carried out bombing strikes inside Iran.

title: Trump claims Russia 'easier' to deal with than Ukraine on peace talks
summary: The US president's comments on his ceasefire negotiations with Russia and Ukraine came after he said he was 'strongly' considering imposing tariffs on Moscow after large-scale overnight attacks on the wartorn country.

title: Service resumes at Paris's Gare du Nord after WWII bomb that halted traffic defused
summary: All traffic at Gare du Nord train station was paused for much of the day after a 500-kilogram bomb dating back to World War II was found. All Eurostar trains to and from Paris on Friday were canceled.

title: A South Carolina man executed by firing squad is the first US prisoner killed this way in 15 years
summary: Brad Sigmon, 67, was pronounced dead at 6:08 pm on Friday after being shot by three volunteer prison employees wielding rifles loaded with live ammunition. He had been convicted of killing his ex-girlfriend's parents with a baseball bat in 2001.

title: Gene Hackman died of natural causes, a week after wife, says medical examiner
summary: The chief medical examiner for the New Mexico Office of the Medical Investigator announced Friday that the late 95-year-old star's wife, Betsy Hackman, died from hantavirus, a pulmonary syndrome. Neither body showed any sign of trauma, nor any indication of carbon monoxide poisoning, which had been an initial suggestion.

title: Trump cuts $400 million in grants and contracts from Columbia University over anti-Semitism claims
summary: The Trump administration said Friday that it's pulling $400 million from Columbia University, canceling grants and contracts because of what the government describes as the Ivy League school's failure to squelch antisemitism on campus.

title: Trump backs down on tariffs amid Wall Street plunge
summary: The US president has postponed part of the tariffs on Canadian and Mexican products until April 2. The stock market's 'Trump bump' has now been totally erased.

title: Macron tells Trump France is a 'loyal and steadfast ally' in NATO, hits back at 'imperialist' Putin
summary: After the summit of EU leaders in Brussels to discuss European defense, Macron told reporters that Russian President Vladimir Putin 'is an imperialist who seeks to rewrite history.'

title: France begins handover of military bases to Senegal
summary: France said earlier this year it was working with Senegal to organize the withdrawal of French troops. The embassy said facilities in certain districts of the capital had been transferred to Senegalese control.

title: Europe decides to take its security into its own hands, without breaking with US
summary: At a European Council summit on Thursday, the EU adopted a €800-billion 'ReArm Europe' plan. But while some are calling for 'strategic autonomy,' other European countries are still counting on America's protection.

title: Former French spy chief sentenced to prison in influence-peddling trial
summary: Bernard Squarcini was accused of using his security contacts for his own gain, including by obtaining confidential information for luxury giant LVMH. He plans to appeal.

title: Gisèle Pelicot's daughter files sex abuse case against convicted father Dominique
summary: Caroline Darian accused Dominique Pelicot of drugging her and committing 'sexual abuse' against her. He is currently serving a 20-year sentence for repeatedly sedating and raping Gisèle Pelicot with dozens of strangers.

title: US added 151,000 jobs last month, though unemployment up to 4.1%
summary: The unemployment rate went up by 0.1 points as the number of jobless Americans rose by 203,000.

title: Centre Pompidou offering free entry this weekend before permanent collection closes
summary: The Paris modern art museum will also host performances before its permanent collection is removed Monday for a five-year renovation.

title: Barcelona's middle class is rising up against the housing crisis
summary: To prevent the tenants being evicted, the town hall bought a building from an investment fund that wanted to turn the apartments into seasonal rentals. A symbolic operation, but a drop in the ocean as the city faces growing housing difficulties.

title: Denmark's spectacular shift from Atlanticism to European defense
summary: Fearing the destabilization of the transatlantic relationship on which its security policy was based, the Nordic country had historically avoided European defense integration.

title: The social problems plaguing Greenland, far from Trump's expansionist rhetoric
summary: The Danish island has many homeless people and one of the highest suicide rates in the world. Social issues are however virtually absent from the debates ahead of an election on March 11 that could be decisive for the territory's future status.

title: Fashion trend: life in red
summary: The tone is set, and this bold color ignites the fashion world. Worn from head to toe, exclusively, with no room for half measures. A series by stylist Emmanuelle Alt and photographer Anthony Seklaoui.

title: What Baltic intelligence agencies say about the risks of peace talks with Russia
summary: As Europe plans to up its defense spending, Estonian, Latvian and Lithuanian services believe that Moscow could be planning to launch a 'possible military confrontation with NATO.'

title: France, seen as the spearhead of European defense, worries Russia
summary: Macron and Putin engaged in a long-distance sparring match about Napoleon and imperialism.

title: Donald Trump tries to rebalance his pro-Russia message on the war in Ukraine, then backtracks
summary: In the space of a few hours on Friday, the US president threatened Russia with additional sanctions and new tariffs, before praising Vladimir Putin for being 'generous.'

title: Bird flu: Layoffs in US federal agencies disrupt monitoring of the health crisis
summary: With 978 cow herds infected by the virus over the past year, the massive lay-offs of federal employees followed by equally brutal attempts to rehire them have led to fears of disruption in monitoring and management of the crisis.

title: From Monet's Water Lilies to Notre-Dame's stained glass, Claire Tabouret's sacred journey
summary: Many expected Daniel Buren or Philippe Parreno, but the 43-year-old artist was chosen to create the cathedral's new stained glass windows. This bold choice consecrates and challenges the resolve of a tenacious worker who was drawn to her artistic destiny at the age of four.

title: Syria's al-Sharaa urges Alawites to surrender after deadly clashes
summary: More than 250 people have been killed since the clashes erupted on Thursday along the country's western coast, which followed other deadly incidents in the area this week, the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights said.

title: In Greece, the voices of the islands' historic inhabitants are being recorded before their stories are lost
summary: For the past year, Aris Katsigiannis has been posting short videos on social media, in which elderly islanders who have lived through war and hardship tell their stories of the country before mass tourism.

title: Two dead, nearly 230 sickened in US measles outbreak, CDC says
summary: Before this outbreak, the last US measles-related death was in 2015, when a Washington state woman died from virus-induced pneumonia while on immunosuppressive medication. The previous fatality was in 2003.

title: 'Are post boxes doomed to disappear from our streets? That's what's happening to them in Denmark'
summary: The country's longstanding operator, PostNord, will deliver its last letter on December 30, to concentrate on its parcel business, given that mail volumes have been collapsing since the turn of the millennium. Some 1,500 employees are likely to lose their jobs, writes Le Monde's journalist Isabelle Chaperon in her column.

title: Six Nations: For France, 'every little defensive error will be costly' against Ireland
summary: France takes on Ireland on Saturday afternoon in Dublin in a key match. Success against the favorites would put the French back in contention for overall victory.

title: Mikhail Khodorkovsky, Russian opponent: 'The Europeans haven't understood Trump and Putin'
summary: A refugee in London since 2015, the ex-oligarch, in an interview with Le Monde, analyzes the power balance between the leaders involved in Russia's war on Ukraine.

title: Syria's new authorities face explosive situation after bloody clashes in Alawite stronghold
summary: The transitional leadership dispatched thousands of soldiers to combat an armed insurrection launched by Assad loyalists. Leader Ahmad al-Sharaa urged his troops to 'avoid any abuses' after civilians were massacred.

title: The forgotten art of sign painting is reviving French streets
summary: Once a defining feature of shopfronts in the early 20th century, sign painting had gradually disappeared. Today, a new generation of artisans is bringing the craft back to life, driven in part by the surge of food and beverage establishments thriving in cities.

title: UK, France, Italy, Germany hail Arab nations plan for Gaza
summary: The plan is a response to US President Donald Trump's proposal that the US could seize control of the Gaza Strip and turn it into 'the Riviera of the Middle East.'

title: Diplomacy: The impossible dialogue with Donald Trump
summary: Emmanuel Macron met with Donald Trump in Washington at the end of February, embracing a 'diplomacy of ostentation' to win over the unpredictable US president. But can there be a right approach to a leader who is eager to break all the rules?

title: Women's pensions take center stage at March 8 demonstrations
summary: The CGT union wants the mobilizations marking International Women's Rights Day in France to be the first step in re-launching the protest against the postponement of the retirement age to 64.
